arm_group.description: Patients in the first 48 hours of non ST-elevation acute coronary syndromes.
Patients with 3 months after hospital discharge for non ST-elevation acute coronary syndromes.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to compare the response to aspirin in the acute phase with the
      late phase of an acute coronary syndrome.

clinical_study.brief_title: Residual Platelet Activity Despite Aspirin Utilization in Coronary Heart Disease

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to compare, in the same population, the response to aspirin in
      the initial phase (first 48 hours) with the late phase (after 3 months of discharge)of a non
      ST elevation acute coronary syndrome (angina or acute myocardial infarction).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Age ≥ 18 years

          -  Confirmed diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome without ST segment elevation, in the
             first 48 hours after the onset of the clinical symptoms

          -  Regular use of aspirin for at least seven days.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Previous use, in the last 7 days, of another antiplatelet agent than aspirin

          -  Use of antivitamin K in the last 3 weeks

          -  Hemoglobin < 10g/dL and / or hematocrit < 30% or > 50%, platelets count < 100.000/mm3
             or > 500.000/mm3, creatinine clearance < 30 mL / minute

          -  Killip class III or IV

          -  Need for vasopressor or inotropic parenteral medication at inclusion in the study

          -  Percutaneous coronary intervention within 30 days or CABG in the last 90 days prior
             to study entry

          -  Current malignancy

          -  Hematologic diseases

          -  Refusal to sign the inform consent form

          -  Unable to attend the second visit (follow-up) for any reason except for death

study_pop.textblock:
70 patients diagnosed with non ST acute coronary syndrome (unstable angina and myocardial
        infarction without ST elevation), with up to 48 hours of evolution from the onset of
        symptoms.

facility.name: Instituto do Coração (Heart Institute) - Clinical Hospitals, University of São Paulo Medical School

clinical_study.official_title: Residual Platelet Activity Despite Aspirin Utilization in Patients With Non ST Elevation Acute Coronary Syndromes: Comparison Between the Acute and Chronic Phases

overall_official.affiliation: Instituto do Coração (Heart Institute) - Clinical Hospitals, University of São Paulo Medical School

oversight_info.authority: Brazil: National Committee of Ethics in Research

primary_outcome.measure: Compare platelet aggregation between the first 48 hours and 3 months after discharge.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Relation between platelet aggregability  and  the composite endpoint of death, myocardial infarction, unstable angina and need for revascularization or hospitalization at 3 months after discharge.
Relation between the atherosclerotic burden by coronary angiography with the platelet aggregation in the first 48 hours.
Relation between C reactive protein and interleukin -6 with levels of platelet aggregation.
Relation between platelet aggregation and the presence or absence of selected polymorphisms.

secondary_outcome.description: Cut point for age 65 y, for glycemia 125 mg/dL, for glycated hemoglobin 6%
secondary_outcome.measure: Platelet aggregation in respect to age, gender, glucose at hospital arrival, glycated hemoglobin, statin, PPI, current smokers, ACE inhibitors, type of ACS presentation.

clinical_study.source: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

collaborator.agency: Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
